chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
There are countless testimonies in the Divine Scriptures where God is proclaimed as merciful and just. The entire text of heavenly words aims to warn the wicked with the fear of God's justice to quickly put an end to their evil deeds, and to encourage the good to remain diligently and humbly in their good deeds. This is so that every wrongdoer, fearing God's fairness, may run to the mercy of divine goodness, and every righteous person, rejoicing in God's mercy, may not neglect the judgment of the most benevolent fairness.

Where perfect mercy and justice exist, the righteous cannot favor sins, nor can the merciful deny forgiveness to those who repent. Therefore, the fact that He is proclaimed as just and merciful makes it clear that forgiveness of sins is granted only to those who repent, and eternal punishment is inflicted only on those who persist in sin.

For this reason, the Psalmist sings: Unless you repent, He will sharpen His sword, He has bent His bow and made it ready, and He has prepared instruments of death in it (Psalm 7:13).

Also, through Isaiah, a similar sentence against the stubborn and despisers of divine mercy is spoken by the divine mouth, in which it is understood that no one obeys divine commands in vain, nor remains in iniquity without punishment. Thus, he says: Wash yourselves, be clean, remove your wicked deeds from my sight; cease from your evils, learn to do good, seek judgment, rescue the oppressed, judge the orphan, and defend the widow. Come, let us reason together, says the Lord. Though your sins are like scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they are red like crimson, they shall be as wool. If you are willing and obedient, you shall eat the good of the land. But if you refuse and rebel, the sword will devour you. For the mouth of the Lord has spoken this (Isaiah 1:16 and following).
chunks.original_latin:
Innumerabilia sunt divinarum testimonia Scripturarum
quibus Deus misericors praedicatur et justus,
nec est aliud quod omnis textus agat coelestis eloquii,
nisi ut malos admoneat timore justitiae Dei celeriter
malis operibus finem ponere, et bonos in bonis operibus
sollicite atque humiliter permanere. Ut scilicet
 et omnis iniquus aequitatem Dei metuens, ad misericordiam
currat justae bonitatis, et omnis justus, de
Dei misericordia gaudens, judicium benignissimae non
negligat aequitatis. Quia ubi est misericordia justitiaque
perfecta, nec favorem potest justus peccatis impendere,
nec indulgentiam conversis misericors abnegare. Ex hoc igitur quod justus et misericors praedicatur,
facillime cognoscitur (al cognoscimus) non
nisi conversis remissionem tribui peccatorum, nec
nisi permanentibus in peccato supplicium sempiternae
damnationis inferri. Propter quod Psalmista sic canit:
Nisi convertamini, gladium suum vibravit, arcum suum
tetendit, et paravit illum, et in eo paravit vasa mortis
 (Psal VII 13). Per Esaiam quoque non dissimilis adversus
contumaces et divinae clementiae contemptores
lata reperitur ore divino sententia, in qua cognoscitur,
nec inaniter quemquam divinis imperiis
obedire, nec impune in iniquitatibus permanere. Sic
ergo dicit: Lavamini, mundi estote, auferte nequitias
vestras ab animis vestris e conspectu oculorum meorum;
desinite a malitiis vestris, discite bonum facere,
inquirite judicium, eripite injuriam accipientem, judicate
pupillo, et justificate viduam, et venite disputemus,
dicit Dominus. Et si fuerint delicta vestra ut phoenicium,
ut nivem dealbabo. Si autem ut coccum, ut lanam
candidam efficiam. Et si volueritis et obaudieritis me,
quae bona sunt terrae, edetis. Si autem nolueritis, neque
obaudieritis me, gladius vos comedet. Os enim Domini
 locutum est hoc (Isa I 16 et seq).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Who, I ask, is so hard or completely foolish that, upon hearing this divine warning, isn't at least compelled by the fear of punishment if not invited to conversion by the promise of delight? Indeed, the one who disregards the divine message will not receive salvation but will be consumed by the sword.

It's shown elsewhere in the same prophet's writings that no one will reach salvation except through conversion. For it is said: If you turn back and mourn, you will be saved (Isaiah 30:15, according to the Septuagint).

In this conditional testimony, God uses both a command and a promise. By saying, If you turn back and mourn, you will be saved, He shows that the promise of salvation entirely depends on the condition of conversion.

This is, therefore, the condition between God and man, that is, between the commanding Lord and the servant asking, between the judge who grants mercy without compromising justice, and the sinner who rightfully expects the mercy of the just judge.

Thus, this Lord, merciful and just, stern and compassionate, says: If you do this, you will have this; if you keep what I say, I will give what you ask; I command you to convert, you ask me for salvation; if you obey the command, you will gain the benefit; if I see the commands carried out, I will grant the requests. If you turn back and mourn, you will be saved.
chunks.original_latin:
Quis rogo est tam
durus aut omnino stolidus, qui in hoc sermone monitionis
supernae, si ad conversionem non invitatur
368 delectatione promissi, non saltem compellatur
terrore supplicii? Contemptorem quippe divini sermonis
non excipiet salus, sed comesturus est gladius. Hinc est quod alio loco in ejusdem prophetae
volumine demonstratur, quia nisi per conversionem
nemo perveniet ad salutem. Sic enim dicitur: Si conversus
fueris et ingemueris, salvus eris (Isai. XXX, 15,
sec. LXX). In hoc testimonio conditionali Deus et
praecepto utitur, et promisso. Dicens quippe, Si conversus
fueris et ingemueris, salvus eris, ostendit ex
conversionis conditione promissionem salutis omnino
pendere. Haec est igitur inter Deum hominemque conditio,
 id est, inter praecipientem Dominum servumque
poscentem, inter judicem qui sine justitia misericordiam
praerogat, et peccatorem qui misericordiam
juste judicantis exspectat. Dicit igitur iste Dominus,
misericors et justus, severus et pius: Si hoc feceris,
hoc habebis; si quod dico custodieris, dabo quod poscis;
ego tibi praecipio conversionem, tu poscis a me
salutem; si parueris praecepto, potieris beneficio; si
jussa fieri videam, postulata concedam: Si conversus
fueris et ingemueris, salvus eris.
